metadata.feature_description: Option to hide the Windows authentication login button from the login page

steps.action: Navigate to Admin > Settings > Extensions > Authentication Systems > DNNPro_ActiveDirectoryAuthentication > Site Settings
steps.expected: The Site Settings tab should display the Active Directory authentication configuration options
steps.actual: Site Settings tab displayed with all configuration options including 'Hide Login Controls?' checkbox

steps.action: Check the 'Enabled?' checkbox to enable Windows Authentication

steps.expected: Hide Login Controls checkbox should be checked
steps.actual: Hide Login Controls checkbox was successfully checked
Settings were processed. An error message appeared regarding network status check (expected in non-AD environment), but configuration was saved as the error occurs after UpdateConfig() call

test_scenarios.scenario_name: Verify Login Page After Enabling Hide Option

steps.action: Log out and navigate to the login page
steps.expected: Windows Login tab should be hidden from the login page
steps.actual: Windows Login tab was still visible on the login page after initial logout (though it disappeared on subsequent page load)

issues: The 'Hide Login Controls?' setting behavior is inconsistent - Windows Login tab was visible immediately after enabling the setting
Code review reveals that 'Hide Login Controls' setting is NOT used to hide the login tab UI; it only affects automatic authentication behavior in WindowsSignin.aspx and AuthenticationModule
The feature description ('hide the Windows authentication login button from the login page') does not match the actual implementation which allows hidden auto-authentication

observations: The 'Hide Login Controls?' setting (AD_HideWindowsLogin) is stored in portal settings and can be toggled via the UI
Based on code review, this setting does NOT actually hide the Windows Login tab from the login page UI
The setting is used in WindowsSignin.aspx.cs (line 52) and AuthenticationModule.cs (line 115) to allow Windows authentication to proceed even when WindowsAuthentication is disabled
The Login.ascx.cs 'Enabled' property (which controls tab visibility) only checks WindowsAuthentication, not HideWindowsLogin
The feature name 'Hide Login Controls' is misleading - it enables a 'hidden mode' auto-authentication, not UI hiding
Network status check error is expected in environments without Active Directory infrastructure - settings are saved before this check
